column1: #text=        Appendicitis Olya Polishchuk Mary Wyers, M.D.Children's Memorial Hospital  Abstract 4 year old male with low-grade fever and abdominal pain Keywords  appendicitis, appendix, abdominal pain, CT
column4: Publication Date: 2004-06-14                History 4 year old male with low-grade fever and abdominal pain   Findings CT: In the right lower quadrant there is a tubular structure originating from the cecum which is enlarged consistant with an inflamed appendix.

column1: #text=Additionally, there is a 5 mm high density appendicolith.
#text=   Diagnosis  Appendicitis    Differential None   Discussion  Appendicitis in children can be diagnosed with an ultrasound or CT.
#text=CT is useful in larger patients or when alternative diagnosis are being considered.
#text=An appendix larger than 6 mm, nonfilling with oral or rectal contrast, appendicolith, and surrounding soft tissue stranding are all findings suggestive of appendicitis.
#text=CT is also useful for evaluation of perforated appendicitis or adjacent abscesses.
#text=E., EMERGENCY IMAGING OF THE ACUTELY ILL OR INJURED CHILD, Lippincott Williams and Wilkins, 2000, 177-193.
